FELLOW CITrzENs--You will form a wrong es-
,ma.e Of the sentiments OF the people OF Delaware,


if they supposed 20 be expressed in newspaper,
printed in Wilmington, called the DelaWare Ga
zette. The Jolly and sheer nonsense, exhibited In
tha, paper, has long excited merriment even in
those who patronize it; but lest citizens Of other
States should do the State of Delaware the injustice
to believe that it represents The sentiments Of the
State, to any considerable extent, let them rcmem
ber that the Editor is inSane->and that the very
name OF .fdams pn!s him in great paroxysm
as water does a dog afflicted with hydrophoba.
The people OF other States therefore, will please
pa don Mr. Uarker for abusing the President on
account of his Message Of the 5th inst respecting
the Georgia violation OF the law OF the land. The
man is mad, he would not abuse the President
TO- executing the laws, as prescribed by his oath.
The man is mad, or he would not speak OF the
President as depriying the State (of Georea) OF
vested right" which he never did nor never can.
The man is mad or he never could speak OF The
President as having alone made the treaty of April
last with the Creek Indians; when, as every body
else knows, it advised and consented TO, almost
unanimously BY the Senate, including the Senator's
from Uelauare. The man is mdd-mad as Iroup
himsel--or he would know tina. the power that


made the treaty at the Indian Springs, could annul


it, especially both of the contracting parties were
in favor Of such course. The man is mad and
decided opponent Of MIR. Adams was heard to say.
that his Message on Georgia affairs was the best
act Of his life. and that condemnation OF such
acts, like that in the Gazette OF the 9th instant,
would insure his re.eLection'


Do not, therefore, fellow citizens, the injustice
of supposing, for moment. that Delaware is gull
ty of approving the censure Of this Gazette mad
man, because the President OF the U. S. will exc
cute the laws agreesbly TO his oath. Let him rave,
semi i.weekly in his Gazette, not as becomes pro-
iessing christian-but one conducting prostitu-


ted press, while constantly harping upon its ndepen.
dence FIAT JUSTITIA.

The Morgan Case-From the New York Commercial
Advertiser of Tuesday last learn that positive proof
been received that MonoAN has been murdered by the
Masons. COL Stone, the Editor Of that paper who
prominent member of the fraternity, says in his paper Of
that day"We have but too much to fear that the
worst is true, and that few misguided, heated deuded
and ignorant masonic fanatics have inflicted wound up
on the fraternity to which have felt pleasure to
belong, which it will require years to heal. and fixed
stain upon the character of the institution, which all the
waters of Niagara cannot wash away"


Further particulars of this affair will be given Tues
day.

full articles.headline:
FOR THE wATcHMAN.

TO PEOPLE OF OTHER STATES.
full articles.article:
FELLOW CITrzENs--You will form a wrong es-
,ma.e Of the sentiments OF the people OF Delaware,


if they supposed 20 be expressed in newspaper,
printed in Wilmington, called the DelaWare Ga
zette. The Jolly and sheer nonsense, exhibited In
tha, paper, has long excited merriment even in
those who patronize it; but lest citizens Of other
States should do the State of Delaware the injustice
to believe that it represents The sentiments Of the
State, to any considerable extent, let them rcmem
ber that the Editor is inSane->and that the very
name OF .fdams pn!s him in great paroxysm
as water does a dog afflicted with hydrophoba.
The people OF other States therefore, will please
pa don Mr. Uarker for abusing the President on
account of his Message Of the 5th inst respecting
the Georgia violation OF the law OF the land. The
man is mad, he would not abuse the President
TO- executing the laws, as prescribed by his oath.
The man is mad, or he would not speak OF the
President as depriying the State (of Georea) OF
vested right" which he never did nor never can.
The man is mad or he never could speak OF The
President as having alone made the treaty of April
last with the Creek Indians; when, as every body
else knows, it advised and consented TO, almost
unanimously BY the Senate, including the Senator's
from Uelauare. The man is mdd-mad as Iroup
himsel--or he would know tina. the power that


made the treaty at the Indian Springs, could annul


it, especially both of the contracting parties were
in favor Of such course. The man is mad and
decided opponent Of MIR. Adams was heard to say.
that his Message on Georgia affairs was the best
act Of his life. and that condemnation OF such
acts, like that in the Gazette OF the 9th instant,
would insure his re.eLection'


Do not, therefore, fellow citizens, the injustice
of supposing, for moment. that Delaware is gull
ty of approving the censure Of this Gazette mad
man, because the President OF the U. S. will exc
cute the laws agreesbly TO his oath. Let him rave,
semi i.weekly in his Gazette, not as becomes pro-
iessing christian-but one conducting prostitu-


ted press, while constantly harping upon its ndepen.
dence FIAT JUSTITIA.

Of this Borough.

full articles.article:
The Morgan Case-From the New York Commercial
Advertiser of Tuesday last learn that positive proof
been received that MonoAN has been murdered by the
Masons. COL Stone, the Editor Of that paper who
prominent member of the fraternity, says in his paper Of
that day"We have but too much to fear that the
worst is true, and that few misguided, heated deuded
and ignorant masonic fanatics have inflicted wound up
on the fraternity to which have felt pleasure to
belong, which it will require years to heal. and fixed
stain upon the character of the institution, which all the
waters of Niagara cannot wash away"


Further particulars of this affair will be given Tues
day.

and other states, but no such importance had been
attached to them, a. induced the House TO order
their being printed. Why was the present memo
rial to be distinguished by such order respecting
IL. II this petition ordered TO be printed all The
hers should be printed too. But, he could see no
good consequence likely to arise, and he should
therefore oppose the motion.


The question being taken on printing, il was neg
aived by large majority; and the petition was OF
dered to lie on the table.


These several petitions, memorials, and rssolu-
tions, with the exception Of tina, presented by MIR.
Barney, we're referred to the appropriate Commit
ices.


The peaker laid before the House the following
communication from the Postmaster General:


Posr OFFICE DEPARTMENT,
18th February, 1897.
SIn In obedience to join. resolution Of the
Senate and House Of Representatives, at their last
session, which required the Postmaster General to
+. cause examination and survey Of the yaii-
Gus routes between Baltimore and Philadelphia,
crossing the Susquehannah at Hare de Grace Fer
ry. Port Deposile and Cone wngo Bridges, and re-.
port to Congress the route which may be best adap
ted Tor permanent post road, with an estimate OF
the expense Of making each OF said routes safe
and convenient for the transportation OF the mail -
have the honor to transmit report made by
General Bernard and Captain Poussin, OF the Enei-
Deer Corps These officers. on my application 10
the Secretary OF War, were ordered on this service,
and they have performed u in very able and salts
factory manner. They were accompanied by gen.
temen highly respectable tor their intelligence and
characier and who possessed an accurate knowledge
OF the routes that were examined


As this report has been drawn with great care
and ability. and eight routes are laid down, with
the data which an estimate is formed Of the ex
pense Of constructing paved road on each, inclu-
ding bridges, comparative view will show the
most igiblt route.


agree with The report. that "in combining dis
tance, gradation, and expense, the route numbered
two has claim to preference"


The distance on this route, from Baltimore to
Philadelphia, overt the Port Deposte bridge, is nine
~ seven miles and sixty six yards. Or the route
numbe, ed one, which is the shortest, and crosses
the Susquehannah a, Havre de Grace, it is ninety
four miles and Two hundred and Fifty six Yards
The expense uf constructing turnpike road on the
former. including the necessary bridges. is estima
ted at one hundred twenty-six thousand eight hun.
dred and thirty nine dollars; and Of the latter. a,
.I.
fifty dollars


have the honor to be, respectfully. your obed-
cnt servant. JOHN MCLEAN.


Hon. JOHN w. TAYLOR,


Speaker Of the House Of Representatives.
